column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Wireless cellular networks have evolved significantly in terms of both channel-adaptive transmission and interference management .
#Text=Early cellular systems were based on the interference avoidance approach and relied on static resource allocation .
#Text=However , current cellular systems allocate resources dynamically based on short-term channel state feedback .
#Text=Interference decoding and cancellation are also implementable in today ’s systems .
#Text=The K -user Gaussian Interference Channel ( GIC ) models a wireless network with K transmit-receive pairs .
#Text=The optimal transmission scheme for the K -user GIC depends on the channel coefficients .
#Text=Simultaneous channel-aware adaptation of multiple transmit-receive pairs requires a good understanding of the optimal scheme for each channel condition .
#Text=The capacity region and sum capacity of the general K -user Gaussian Interference Channel ( GIC ) are not known .
#Text=The 2-user GIC is the most well understood special case .
#Text=The capacity region of the 2-user GIC under strong interference conditions was obtained in References .
#Text=The sum capacity when the interference can be treated as noise was obtained in References .
#Text=The sum capacity under mixed interference conditions was obtained in Reference .
#Text=The capacity region of the 2-user GIC within one bit was derived in Reference using suitably chosen Han-Kobayashi ( HK ) schemes .
#Text=For the general K -user GIC , the channel conditions under which Treating Interference as Noise ( TIN ) achieves sum capacity were obtained in References ( Thm . 3 ) and ( Thm . 9 ) .
#Text=The sum capacity of some partially connectedK user GICs were derived in Reference under some channel conditions .

#Text=Z -like GICs , where the channel matrix is upper triangular with a specific structure , were studied in Reference , cascade GIC was studied in Reference and many-to-one and one-to-many GICs were studied in References .
#Text=Some new outer bounds on the capacity of the K -user GIC were recently derived in Reference .
#Text=Simple HK ( S-HK ) schemes with Gaussian signalling , no timesharing and no common-private power splitting , achieve sum capacity under the channel conditions obtained in References .
#Text=S-HK schemes include the simple and practical TIN scheme and schemes that involve various levels of interference decoding and cancellation at each receiver as special cases .
#Text=For the 2-user GIC , S-HK schemes are sufficient to achieve all known sum capacity results .
#Text=For the K -user GIC , we will generalize the sum capacity optimality results for the TIN scheme in References , to S-HK schemes .
#Text=There are some other related results for the symmetric GIC or for GICs where the channel coefficients satisfy some equality conditions , respectively .

#Text=For a K -user interference channel , the sum capacity under a strong interference condition was obtained in Reference under conditions that include some equality conditions on the channel coefficients .
#Text=Equality conditions cannot be satisfied if the channel coefficients come from continuous distributions .
#Text=The symmetric K -user GIC and many-to-one GIC have been considered in References , respectively .

#Text=Unlike the other results discussed above based on S-HK schemes , in References , lattice coding and interference alignment are used to obtain the sum capacity when the interference is very strong .
#Text=For the general asymmetric GIC , only approximate sum capacity and degrees of freedom results have been obtained using interference alignment .
#Text=Other structured codes like coset codes have also been studied in Reference to show achievable sum rates better than those achieved by HK schemes for some 3-user interference channels .
#Text=Interference alignment and structured codes are useful under channel conditions where HK schemes are not optimal .
#Text=We identify channel conditions where S-HK schemes are sum capacity optimal for the K -user GIC .
#Text=In this paper , we generalize the sum capacity optimality results for the TIN scheme in References to S-HK schemes .
#Text=In particular , we derive two sets of channel conditions under which S-HK schemes are sum capacity optimal for general K -user GICs .
#Text=For the first set of channel conditions , we consider schemes where interference is decoded and cancelled before decoding the desired message .
#Text=For the second set of channel conditions , we consider schemes where the one interference signal is jointly decoded with the message signal at one of the receivers .
#Text=These two sets of channel conditions provide us new sum capacity results for several channel conditions under which sum capacity was not known earlier .
#Text=Furthermore , existing results for the sum capacity of the 2-user GIC and some partially connected K user GICs in References can be obtained as special cases of these results .

#Text=To further understand the significance of the results , we evaluate , using Monte Carlo simulations , the probability that these channel conditions for sum capacity are satisfied for random wireless networks .
#Text=Three different random network models are considered and we observe that this probability is significant under all three models .
